items.htmltext: Our paper Modeling the amplification of epidemic spread by individuals exposed to misinformation on social media was accepted for publication at npj Complexity.
Accepted an offer to join the <a href='https://sml.stanford.edu/' target='_blank'>Stanford Social Media Lab<a> as a postdoctoral researcher!
Was accepted to the <a href='https://ntmi.lakecomoschool.org/' target='_blank'>Lake Como School of Advanced Studies<a>.
Gave an invited talk at SPSP as part of the Misinformation and Belief Science preconference.
Our work Fact-checking information from large language models can decrease headline discernment was published in PNAS.

Our work Information diffusion assumptions can distort our understanding of social network dynamics was accepted for an oral presentation at CS2Italy (Conference On Computational Social Science) and will be presented by my coauthor Francesco Pierri.
Information diffusion assumptions can distort our understanding of social network dynamics.
üé§ Jo Lukito from the University of Texas at Austin‚Äôs School of Journalism and Media gave a talk as part of the Observatory's Awesome Speakers event. Watch it here.
I was invited to give a talk about our work about how humans interact with LLM fact checks for the wonderful folks at UPenn's Social Action Lab.
Our work Fact-checking information from large language models can decrease headline discernment was accepted for a lightening talk at Stanford's Trust and Safety Research Conference.

I was invited to give a talk about our work identifying and characterizing superspreaders of low-credibility content for the wonderful folks at Cornell Tech's Security, Trust, and Safety (SETS) Initiative.
Had a great time speaking on the 'Data is Everything: Data's Role in Social Advancement and Technological Growth' panel for the 2024 Luddy Precollege Program.
üí• Honored to receive $7,000 in OpenAI Researcher Access Program credits to study LLM fact checking. üôè
ABC Australia covered our paper Identifying and characterizing superspreaders of low-credibility content on Twitter.
IFL Science covered our paper Identifying and characterizing superspreaders of low-credibility content on Twitter.
Featured in Mozilla's AI Intersections Database, which maps where AI impacts meet social justice issues and catalogs the people and organizations working to make AI equitable for all.
üé§ Sinan Aral from Massachusetts Institute of Technology gave a talk as part of the Observatory's Awesome Speakers event. Watch it here

Invited to serve as a Program Committee member of the Social Media Sway workshop taking place at the International Conference on Advances in Social Networks Analysis and Mining (ASONAM).
Just Security covered our Top FIBers dashboard in their piece How to Combat Emerging Global Social Media Manipulation in 2024.
üé§ David Rand from Massachusetts Institute of Technology gave a talk as part of the Observatory's Awesome Speakers event. Watch it here.
üí• Honored that I was selected to join the 2024 Future Leaders Summit organized by the Michigan Institute for Data Science (MIDAS) at the University of Michigan. üôè

Modeling the amplification of epidemic spread by misinformed populations.
üé§ David Lazer from Northeastern University gave a talk as part of the Observatory's Awesome Speakers event. Watch it here.
Honored to receive a $5,000 fellowship from the Institute for Humane Studies. üôè

Thrilled to announce that I will be co-organizing the Fifth International Cyber Social Threats workshop at the International Conference on Web and Social Media (2024). üí• Make sure to submit your work!
Honored to receive a $5,000 minigrant from the Civic Health Project to develop an LLM-powered extension to reduce toxic polarization! üôè
il Post covered (in Italian) our paper Online misinformation is linked to early COVID-19 vaccination hesitancy and refusal.
The IMAGINE IU magazine covered the Top FIBers dashboard.
üé§ Ren√©e DiResta from the Stanford Internet Observatory gave a talk as part of the Observatory's Awesome Speakers event. Watch it here.
üé§ Ceren Budak from the School of Information at the University of Michigan gave a talk as part of the Observatory's Awesome Speakers event. Watch it here.

Francesco Pierri will be presenting work from our project 'Misinformed populations can amplify the spread of disease' at the European Digital Media Observatory (EDMO) Scientific Conference on Disinformation.
The AP News covered our paper One Year of COVID-19 Vaccine Misinformation on Twitter.
üé§ Brendan Nyhan from Dartmouth's Department of Governance gave a talk as part of the Observatory's Awesome Speakers event. Watch it here.
üé§ Franziska Roesner from UW's Information School gave a talk as part of the Observatory's Awesome Speakers event. There is no recording of this one but you can watch others here.

üé§ Gianluca Stringhini from BU's Security Lab (SeclaBU) gave a talk as part of the Observatory's Awesome Speakers event. Watch it here.
ü•Ç Artificial intelligence is ineffective and potentially harmful for fact checking was accepted for a poster presentation at CODE@MIT. Let me know if you'll be in Boston!
Honored to receive a $10,000 Trust and Safety scholarship from Cognizant. üôè
üé§ Joshua Tucker from NYU's Center for Social Media and Politics gave a talk as part of the Observatory's Awesome Speakers event. Watch it here.
Kai-Cheng Yang presented our paper Artificial intelligence is ineffective and potentially harmful for fact checking at the 2023 Politics and Computational Social Science Conference.
Fact-checking information generated by a large language model can decrease news discernment.
I was interviewed by WISH-TV about the Top FIBers tool.
The Times of India covered our Top FIBers tool.
Created an interactive dashboard called Top FIBers that tracks and reports on the top superspreaders of low-credibility information on Twitter and Facebook each month.
During the spring semester I had the pleasure of mentoring Ashley Zeigler as part of Indiana University's Undergraduate Research Opportunities in Computing (UROC) program.
I will be serving as a guest editor for EPJ Data Science's special issue Computational Approaches for Cyber Social Threats. üí• Make sure to submit your manuscript! üí•
My work reconstructing social media cascades to identify misinformation amplifiers was accepted for a poster at the International Conference on Computational Social Science!
My work reconstructing social media cascades to identify misinformation amplifiers was accepted for a talk at NetSci!
I was recognized with the Informatics department's Luddy Outstanding Service Award ($500).
Spoke on Indiana Newsdesk about our paper One Year of COVID-19 Vaccine Misinformation on Twitter.
üí• Online misinformation is linked to early COVID-19 vaccination hesitancy and refusal was cited in the 2023 Economic Report of the President. üí•
üß® Online misinformation is linked to early COVID-19 vaccination hesitancy and refusal was listed in Scientific Reports Top 100 most downloaded articles of 2022 . üß®
One year of COVID-19 vaccine misinformation on Twitter published in the Journal of Medical Internet Research.
Cyber Social Threats workshop at The Web Conference (2023) was accepted!
Accepted into the Twitter Developer Student Ambassador Program!
Very honored to have been awarded the Best Student Extended Abstract award at MISDOOM 2022! üéâ
I spoke about our work at the Truth and Trust Online conference (TTO) today! Check out some pictures the conference shared on Twitter about my talk here.
I spoke about our work at the Multidisciplinary International Symposium on Disinformation in Open Online Media (MISDOOM) today!

Former Dominican Republic President Leonel Fern√°ndez visited the Observatory on Social Media and I gave a demonstration of a visualization tool called 'MisAmplifiers' that identifies hidden amplifiers of misinformation on Twitter.
Spoke as a panelist at NYU about the PhD application process for currently applying MA students.
Rumors in Retweet: Ideological Asymmetry in the Failure to Correct Misinformation was published in Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin.
Identification and characterization of misinformation superspreaders on social media.
One year of COVID-19 vaccine misinformation on Twitter.
Had a wonderful conversation on the Misinformation in Science and Society (MISS) YouTube Channel.
Co-organized the third annual Cyber Social Threats workshop at ICWSM.
Information Disorder Prize Competition (Aspen Tech Policy Hub): Semi-finalist ($5,000).
Invited as a speaker for the Hacking Online Virality event at the University of Minnesota's Learning Informatics Lab.

New York Times Magazine covered our recent publication Online misinformation is linked to early COVID-19 vaccination hesitancy and refusal in a piece about the anti-vaccination movement's 'new frontier.'
Time covered our recent publication Online misinformation is linked to early COVID-19 vaccination hesitancy and refusal in a piece discussing childhood vaccination rates and misinformation.

Tech Policy Press covered our publication Online misinformation is linked to early COVID-19 vaccination hesitancy and refusal in a piece discussing evidence linking misinformation to vaccine hesitancy from multiple studies.
Online misinformation is linked to early COVID-19 vaccination hesitancy and refusal was published in Scientific Reports.
Created a Python package called py_misinfo_exposure to calculate a Twitter user's misinformation-exposure score (based on Mosleh and Rand, 2021).
Invited to give a demonstration of osometweet on Twitter's official Twitch channel (Jupyter notebook; this notebook may be outdated if the package is updated).
Released the first version of osometweet ‚Äî a Python package designed for academics to access Twitter's V2 API.
Invited as a speaker for the Knight Research Network Tool Demonstration Day (CoVaxxy).
Invited by the ACHA CoVAC Initiative to speak at the Managing COVID-19 Vaccine Misinformation on Campus webinar.
Accepted by the Networks Conference to give a presentation about identifying superspreaders of misinformation on Twitter.
Invited to give a demonstration of CoVaxxy at ICWSM.
Axios covered the CoVaxxy dashboard in a piece about vaccine trust.
AP News covered the CoVaxxy dashboard in a deep dive about Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
CoVaxxy: A Collection of English Language Twitter Posts about COVID-19 Vaccines was published in the ICWSM proceedings.
Released CoVaxxy ‚Äî a web-based data visualization dashboard for visualizing the relationship between (mis)information and vaccine adoption in the United States.
Gave a presentation about my research for the Computer and Information Ethics course at Indiana University.
Joined the IU Graduate Professional Student Government as a representative for the Informatics program (PhD).
Awarded a Knight Research Fellowship.
Began working with the Observatory on Social Media and Dr. Filippo Menczer's research group, Networks and Agents Networks.
Accepted by Indiana University's Informatics PhD program (Complex Networks and Systems track)! üï∫üèª
Graduated from NYU with General Psychology MA.
Masters Research Award, New York University ($500).
